API Reference¶

Type aliases¶

using icey::Node = NodeWithIceyContext<rclcpp::Node>¶
using icey::LifecycleNode = NodeWithIceyContext<rclcpp_lifecycle::LifecycleNode>¶
using icey::Timer = TimerStream¶
template<class T>
using icey::Parameter = ParameterStream<T>¶
using icey::Clock = std::chrono::system_clock¶
using icey::Time = std::chrono::time_point<Clock>¶
using icey::Duration = Clock::duration¶

Functions¶

template<class N = Node>
static auto icey::create_node(int argc, char **argv, const std::string &node_name)¶
template<class Node>
static void icey::spin(Node node)¶

Blocking spawn of an existing node.

static void icey::spin_nodes(const std::vector<std::shared_ptr<Node>> &nodes)¶
template<class T>
static void icey::declare_parameter_struct(Context &ctx, T &params, const std::function<void(const std::string&)> &notify_callback, std::string name_prefix = "")¶

Declare all fields of a given parameter struct as ROS parameters.

Template Parameters:

T – the type of the Parameter struct. It is a struct with fields of either a primitive type supported by ROS (e.g. double) or a icey::ParameterStream, or another (nested) struct with more such fields.

Parameters:

  • ctx – the icey-Context, required for registering the parameters.

  • params – The instance of the parameter struct where the values will be written to.

  • notify_callback – The callback that gets called when any field changes

  • name_prefix – Prefix for each parameter. Used by the recursive call to support nested structs.

Fundamentals¶

struct Nothing¶

A special type that indicates that there is no value. (Using void for this would cause many problems, so defining an extra struct is easier.)

template<class _Value, class _ErrorValue>
struct Result : private std::variant<std::monostate, _Value, _ErrorValue>, public icey::ResultTag¶

A Result-type like in Rust, it is a sum type that can either hold Value or Error, or, different to Rust, none.

Public Types

using Value = _Value¶
using ErrorValue = _ErrorValue¶
using Self = Result<_Value, _ErrorValue>¶

Public Functions

bool has_none() const¶
bool has_value() const¶
bool has_error() const¶
const Value &value() const¶
const ErrorValue &error() const¶
void set_none()¶
void set_ok(const Value &x)¶
void set_err(const ErrorValue &x)¶

Public Static Functions

static Self None()¶
static Self Ok(const _Value &x)¶
static Self Err(const _ErrorValue &x)¶

Streams¶

These are all the available Streams, implementing subscribers, publishers/timers etc.

template<typename _Value, typename _ErrorValue = Nothing, typename Derived = Nothing>
class Stream : public icey::StreamTag¶

An stream, basis for all other streams. Similar to a promise in JavaScript.

Subclassed by icey::InterpolateableStream< geometry_msgs::msg::TransformStamped, TransformSubscriptionStreamImpl >

Public Types

using Impl = impl::Stream<_Value, _ErrorValue, WithDefaults<Derived>, WithDefaults<Nothing>>¶
using Value = typename Impl::Value¶
using ErrorValue = typename Impl::ErrorValue¶
using Self = Stream<_Value, _ErrorValue, Derived>¶
using promise_type = Self¶

Promise type alias for supporting C++20’s coroutines.

Public Functions

Stream()¶
~Stream()¶
void assert_we_have_context()¶
std::string get_type_info() const¶
std::shared_ptr<Impl> impl() const¶

Returns the undelying pointer to the implementation.

template<typename F>
auto then(F &&f)¶

Creates a new Stream that changes it’s value to y every time the value x of the parent stream changes, where y = f(x).

template<typename F>
auto except(F &&f)¶

Creates a new Stream that reveices the error.

template<class T, typename ...Args>
void publish(Args&&... args)¶

Creates a ROS publisher by creating a new stream of type T and connecting it to this stream.

template<class O, typename ...Args>
auto create_stream(Args&&... args)¶

Creates an arbitrary new stream through the Context.

TimeoutFilter<Value> timeout(rclcpp::Duration max_age, bool create_extra_timer = true)¶

Returns a new Stream that sets an error on a timeout.

Parameters:

create_extra_timer – If set to true, an extra ROS-timer will be started so that a timeout error is set independent if any value is received in this Stream or not.

void publish(const std::string &topic_name, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::SystemDefaultsQoS())¶

Publish the value of this Stream.

void publish_transform()¶

Publish a transform using the TFBroadcaster in case this Stream holds a Value of type geometry_msgs::msg::TransformStamped.

template<class ServiceT>
auto call_service(const std::string &service_name, const Duration &timeout, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::ServicesQoS())¶

Create a new ServiceClient stream, this stream holds the request.

auto unpack()¶

Unpacks an Stream holding a tuple as value to multiple Streams for each tuple element. Given that Value is of type std::tuple<Value1, Value2, …, ValueN>, this returns std::tuple< Stream<Value1>, Stream<Value2>, ..., Stream<ValueN>>

Self get_return_object()¶
std::suspend_never initial_suspend()¶

Third, we never already got something since this is a stream (we always first need to spin the ROS executor to get a message), so we never suspend:

Value return_value()¶

Fourth, we return_value returns the value of the promise:

template<class T>
void return_value(const T &x) const¶

Fifth, if the return_value function is called with a value, it sets the value, makes sense right ? No ? Oh .. (Reference: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20210330-00/?p=105019)

void unhandled_exception()¶

Sixth, we already handle exceptions in the promise.

std::suspend_never final_suspend() const noexcept¶

Seventh, we do not need to do anything at the end, no extra cleanups needed.

template<class ReturnType>
auto await_transform(ReturnType x)¶

Eight, promisify a value if needed, meaning if it is not already a promise and set context since we need to have the executor

void spin_executor()¶

Spin the event loop, (the ROS executor) until this Promise is fulfilled.

bool await_ready()¶

Now the Awaiter interface for C++20 coroutines: Do we have a value ?

bool await_suspend(auto)¶

Spin the ROS event loop until we got a value.

auto await_resume()¶

Consume the result and return it.

template<class NewVal, class NewErr>
Stream<NewVal, NewErr> create_from_impl(const std::shared_ptr<impl::Stream<NewVal, NewErr, WithDefaults<Nothing>, WithDefaults<Nothing>>> &impl) const¶

Pattern-maching factory function that creates a New Self with different value and error types based on the passed implementation pointer. (this is only needed for impl::Stream::done, which creates a new stream that always has Derived stripped off, i.e. set to Nothing.)

Public Members

std::shared_ptr<Impl> impl_ = {impl::create_stream<Impl>()}¶

The pointer to the undelying implementation (i.e. PIMPL idiom).

template<typename _Value>
struct ParameterStream : public icey::Stream<_Value, Nothing, ParameterStreamImpl<_Value>>¶

An stream for ROS parameters. Fires initially an event if a default_value set.

Public Functions

ParameterStream(const std::optional<_Value> &default_value, const Validator<_Value> &validator = Validator<_Value>(), std::string description = "", bool read_only = false, bool ignore_override = false)¶

A more traditional constructor.

void register_with_ros(NodeBookkeeping &node)¶
const _Value &value() const¶

Parameters are initialized always at the beginning, so they always have a value.

operator _Value() const¶

Allow implicit conversion to the stored value type for consistent API between constrained and non-constrained parameters when using the parameter structs.

NOLINT

template<class Value>
struct Interval¶

What follows, is an improved parameters API. For API docs, see https://docs.ros.org/en/jazzy/p/rcl_interfaces First, some constraints we can impose on parameters: A closed interval, meaning a value must be greater or equal to a minimum value and less or equal to a maximal value.

Public Functions

Interval(Value minimum, Value maximum)¶

TODO make two template params and use common_type + CTAD to make a really nice UX.

Value maximum¶

struct Set¶

template<class Value>
struct Validator¶

Public Types

using ROSValue = std::conditional_t<std::is_unsigned_v<Value>, int, Value>¶

In ROS, parameters can only be of certain types.

The type of the predicate.

Public Functions

Validate validate¶

A predicate that indicates whether a given value is feasible. By default, a validator always returns true since the parameter is unconstrained

template<typename _Message>

Actual implementation of Stream¶

template<typename _Value, typename _ErrorValue, typename Derived, typename DefaultDerived>
class Stream : private boost::noncopyable, public Derived, public std::enable_shared_from_this<Stream<_Value, _ErrorValue, Derived, DefaultDerived>>¶

A stream, conceptually very similar to a promise in JavaScript but the state transitions are not final. I saw that these implementations are very close to mine: [1] https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_67_0/libs/fiber/doc/html/fiber/synchronization/futures/promise.html [2] https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20210406-00/?p=105057 And for a thread-safe implementation at the cost of insane complexity, see this: [3] https://github.com/lewissbaker/cppcoro/blob/master/include/cppcoro/task.hpp

Public Types

using Value = _Value¶
using ErrorValue = _ErrorValue¶
using Self = Stream<Value, ErrorValue, Derived, DefaultDerived>¶
using MaybeValue = std::optional<Value>¶
using State = Result<Value, ErrorValue>¶
using Handler = std::function<void(const State&)>¶

Public Functions

bool has_none() const¶
bool has_value() const¶
bool has_error() const¶
const Value &value() const¶
const ErrorValue &error() const¶
State &get_state()¶
const State &get_state() const¶
void register_handler(Handler cb)¶
void set_none()¶

TODO disable_if these hold Nothing.

void set_value(const MaybeValue &x)¶

TODO remove handling of optional.

void set_error(const ErrorValue &x)¶
void notify()¶

Notify about error or value, depending on the state. If there is no value, it does not notify.

Filters¶

The following filters handle synchronization, serialization timeout and other operations on streams.

template<typename _Message, class _Base = Stream<typename _Message::SharedPtr>>
struct SimpleFilterAdapter : public icey::Stream<typename _Message::SharedPtr>, public message_filters::SimpleFilter<_Message>¶

Adapts the message_filters::SimpleFilter to our Stream (which is a similar concept). Note that this is the same as what message_filters::Subscriber does: https://github.com/ros2/message_filters/blob/humble/include/message_filters/subscriber.h#L349

Public Functions

SimpleFilterAdapter()¶

Constructs a new instance and connects this Stream to the message_filters::SimpleFilter so that signalMessage is called once a value is received. .. todo:: Use mfl::simplefilter as derive-impl, then do not capture this, and do not allocate this adapter dynamically but statically, and pass impl() (which will be then message_filters::SimpleFilter<_Message> ) to the synchroniuzer as input.

template<typename ...Messages>
class SynchronizerStream : public icey::Stream<std::tuple<Messages::SharedPtr...>, std::string, SynchronizerStreamImpl<Messages...>>¶

Public Types

using Self = SynchronizerStream<Messages...>¶

Public Functions

explicit SynchronizerStream(uint32_t queue_size)¶
template<typename ...Messages>
struct SynchronizerStreamImpl¶

TODO this needs to check whether all inputs have the same QoS, so we will have do a walk TODO adapt queue size automatically if we detect very different frequencies so that synchronization still works. I would guess currently it works only if the lowest frequency topic has a frequency of at least 1/queue_size, given the highest frequency topic has a frequency of one.

Public Types

using Policy = message_filters::sync_policies::ApproximateTime<Messages...>¶

Approx time will work as exact time if the stamps are exactly the same, so I wonder why the TImeSynchronizer uses by default ExactTime

using Sync = message_filters::Synchronizer<Policy>¶

Context¶

The context owns all the Streams.

class Context : public std::enable_shared_from_this<Context>¶

The context owns the streams.

Public Functions

template<class O, typename ...Args>
auto create_stream(Args&&... args)¶

Creates a new stream of type O by passing the args to the constructor. It adds the impl to the list of streams so that it does not go out of scope. It also sets the context

Public Static Functions

template<class Reference, class ...Interpolatables>
static auto sync_with_reference(Reference reference, Interpolatables... interpolatables)¶

Synchronizer that given a reference signal at its first argument, ouputs all the other topics.

template<typename ...Parents>
static SynchronizerStream<obs_msg<Parents>...> synchronize_approx_time(Parents... parents)¶

Synchronizer that synchronizes non-interpolatable signals by matching the time-stamps approximately

template<typename ...Parents>
static auto synchronize(Parents... parents)¶

Synchronize a variable amount of Streams. Uses a Approx-Time synchronizer if the inputs are not interpolatable or an interpolation-based synchronizer based on a given (non-interpolatable) reference. Or, a combination of both, this is decided at compile-time.

template<typename ...Parents>
static auto serialize(Parents... parents)¶

Serialize, pipe arbitrary number of parents of the same type into one. Needed for the control-flow where the same publisher can be called from multiple callbacks

ROS-related¶

class NodeBookkeeping¶

Implements holding the shared pointers to subscribers/timers/publishers etc., i.e. provides bookeeping, so that the API user does not have to do it.

NodeInterfaces node_¶
IceyBook book_¶

Public Static Functions

static std::string extend_name_with_sub_namespace(const std::string &name, const std::string &sub_namespace)¶

The internal rclcpp::Node does not consistently call the free function (i.e. rclcpp::create_*) but instead prepends the sub_namespace. (on humble) This seems to me like a patch, so we have to apply it here as well. This is unfortunate, but needed to support both lifecycle nodes and regular nodes without templates.

struct IceyBook¶

Do not force the user to do the bookkeeping themselves: Do it instead automatically.

Public Members

Some extra baggage we can have as an extention point.

struct NodeInterfaces¶

A helper to abstract regular rclrpp::Nodes and LifecycleNodes. Similar to the NodeInterfaces class: https://github.com/ros2/rclcpp/pull/2041 but it’s not coming for Humble. So I did something similar. Mind also that NodeInterfaces is not yet supported by geometry2/TF: https://github.com/ros2/geometry2/issues/698

Public Functions

template<class _Node>
explicit NodeInterfaces(_Node *node)¶
auto get_node_base_interface() const¶

This getter is needed for ParameterEventHandler. Other functions likely require this interface too.

rclcpp::Node *maybe_regular_node = {nullptr}¶

This is set to either of the two, depending on which node we got. It has to be a raw pointer since this nodeInterface is needed during node construction

rclcpp_lifecycle::LifecycleNode *maybe_lifecycle_node = {nullptr}¶
struct TFListener¶

A transform listener that allows to subscribe on a single transform between two coordinate systems. It is implemented similarly to the tf2_ros::TransformListener, but without a separate node. The implementation currently checks for relevant transforms (i.e. ones we subscribed) every time a new message is receved on /tf. We could speed up the code a bit here (not sure if significantly), for this we could obtain the path in the TF tree between the source- and target-frame using tf2::BufferCore::_chainAsVector and then only react if any transform was received that is part of this path.

Public Types

using TransformMsg = geometry_msgs::msg::TransformStamped¶
using OnTransform = std::function<void(const TransformMsg&)>¶
using OnError = std::function<void(const tf2::TransformException&)>¶

Public Functions

explicit TFListener(NodeInterfaces node)¶
void add_subscription(const std::string &target_frame, const std::string &source_frame, const OnTransform &on_transform, const OnError &on_error)¶

Add notification for a single transform.

Public Members

NodeInterfaces node_¶
std::shared_ptr<tf2_ros::Buffer> buffer_¶

We take a tf2_ros::Buffer instead of a tf2::BufferImpl only to be able to use ROS-time API (internally TF2 has it’s own timestamps…), not because we need to wait on anything (that’s what tf2_ros::Buffer does in addition to tf2::BufferImpl).

template<class NodeType>
class NodeWithIceyContext : public NodeType¶

The ROS node, additionally owning the context that holds the Streams.

Template Parameters:

NodeType – can either be rclcpp::Node or rclcpp_lifecycle::LifecycleNode, meaning it is used to support lifecycle_nodes
